reviews.text: Very touristy but worth it in my opinion. This seemed to be the hottest part of death valley we experienced, so make sure you bring water if you decide to hike out aways.

This is the bucket list place in Death Valley National Park.  It's a drive from Furnace creek but well worth it.  As you are driving you would swear you are looking at ice but then you realize its salt.  They have a sign that shows where the sea level is and you are at least 200 ft below!
a classic payload map. one of the most important maps in the game, up there with upward.

A must do in Death Valley, Badwater was absolutely amazing. The salt pan is really beautiful and it really is cool walking out on it. Look out on the cliff behind for a sea level sign about half way up the cliff.
Quite a very high up place! Never ever be afraid of heights! Go there if you dare
Awesome stop off on road to Bad Water basin, its unpaved an quite bumpy at times. Saw many sedans handle it well. Worth the 5 minute drive

One of the harshest landscapes in Death Valley. Can be accessed from many ways. We had taken a short 2 mile road with lots of gravel. It's a bumpy ride if you do not have proper vehicle. Can be covered in 20 min. 
If you are wondering how the name came, It was named after a line in the 1934 National Park Service guide book to Death Valley National Monument, which stated that "Only the devil could play golf" on its surface, due to a rough texture from the large halite salt crystal formations.
Surreal place to visit. One of the harshest landscapes you can imagine, which makes it eerily beautiful. Easy accessed off of the main Death Valley highway by a short well-graded dirt road.
This is in Death Valley National Park. Very interesting place to visit. The Devil's Golf Course is from large clumps of salt crystals.
Amazing how the Salt makes fragile golf ball size formations!  A must see to believe!
Worth seeing while at Bryce Canyon. No hiking require. Just park your car and walk 100 to 300 feet depending what parking space is available.

Been here, done that ... want more
If you have not been here ... GO HERE IMMEDIATELY .... WOW ... this place takes your breath away.

I can not go back fast enough.

To save time on all the places up here to review ... they are all 5 ... do them all and take your time and enjoy it.
Cool place. Buts not really a bridge. It's an arch
This pace was so cool. Come here to see the natural Bridge! You're really not expecting it down the canyon wall and then bam--there it is! Awesome!
Just a beautiful view with color painted constant changes. Is a must see oic you are anyplace neat.  That whole entire area Bryce Cayon included is a sight to see.

Strangely Death Valley National Park does not have a staffed western entry kiosk. You have to pay entrance fee either here or at furnace Creek. There is also an automatic payment machine when the ranger station is closed. It's the honor system.

It's not a full ranger station, only one room. The rangers are very helpful. There are small selection of gifts for sale.
It was closed. No maps. 30.00 per vehicle per week. Road closures with no warning signs so you waste time and gas. Fabulous. 3/18/2018
Renewed my annual pass, others were getting day passes, maps, and back country advice. Personnel were polite and quick. There was a short line.
A hand full of tshirts may help. The ranger was so pleasant and helpful!
Ranger was rude and very condescending. Was not polite or helpful.

It's almost surreal, entering this ravine in the middle of the desert that gets progressively greener and cooler, and eventually running water appears and finally after a modest scramble over rocks and mud (I did see a few elderly people turn back owing to the unsteady footings in spots, so be prepared for that), coming to the falls themselves. It's pretty amazing. Road out there isn't terrible, but it's not great. We made it in our stupid little Prius, but you'd do far better in a truck. Also highly recommended.
Who said there is no water in Death Valley.  More than ever, please respect this rare oasis, stay on the trail, watch for the vegetation.  Please Leave No Trace!
Worth the drive and the walk. Very beautiful in the middle of the desert. Small one though

Easy hike and worth it.  Maybe bring your hiking pole or poles for balance on slippery spots.  There was no sign for the hike by the road so look for the white pipe against the rock wall on a dirt road off the highway near Panamint Springs.
Surprisingly awesome waterfall in the middle of death Valley. Hike had some scrambling, but was short and easy
Leave something for the family God bless charle manson
Fun off road day. Made it from Ballarat, past Mengel Pass and to 190 no problem at night. Always changing terrain though. Route taken in Dec. 2018

Need 4wd for one rock that’s currently being watered by a spring a few yards up.  2wd and a solid bump could make it up.  
Aside from the 1 “obstacle” 2wd and suv clearance can make it.  Ranch was nice- folks are doing a good job of keeping trash picked up.  

If you plan to go further up the trail say a mile or so north of Barker ranch.  High clearance is a must... skid plates are a must- you will use the skids unless your lifted....
Amazing. 4x4 needed.
An obscure and sad, but real site of California's history.
Loved it!!
A must to hike. Sit on top a while and take in the view.
The countless bizarre rocks were an unexpected treat on the easy hike over to the dunes.

We were staying at over one of the nearby campgrounds and decided to spend a day by the pool here. They offer pool pass and at the time we went they were $10 per person per day. The pool was super nice and clean, so are the restrooms. They offer towels here too, so you don't need to bring your own. Also around noon they start their poolside service if drinks and food. Very peaceful.

We came here for a shower and a meal while camping at death valley. The staff at the pool were so welcoming and helped us with pool passes, drinks, and even got us reservations for dinner that evening. Tucker you are the best. We then went upstairs and had wonderful drinks. We came back the following evening for pre-dinner snacks. I absolutely suggest visitors of death valley make time to check this place out. Wonderful place for a break from camping and enjoy some luxury in the desert.

Shame they haven't remodelled the rooms! We were told we had been 'upgraded' as the room type we had booked was under maintenance... I'd hate to see what the other room looked like. Massively overpriced. It would have been nice if the reception staff when checking us in had bothered to enquire if we had made any dinner reservations (restaurant turned out to be fully booked), or told us the other dinner option closed at 8pm. Pool was very nice, only good thing to be said.

The Inn's prices are steep for a small room with very few amenities. While clean, the staff needs training as to proper house keeping requirements i.e. soap refills, hangers in the closet, door latch inoperative. The Inn's restaurant is likewise expensive, but understandable given its location. The menu offerings are limited and the portions are small. Having stayed at the ranch, there is much more value there. Their recent remodel took away much of the charm and added lots of expense.

A bit of unexpected beauty and history amidst the inhospitable expanse of Death Valley. The cave-like entrance is interesting. That it leads to such a polished and welcoming space is surprising and appreciated. Good drinks too!

We were staying at over one of the nearby campgrounds and decided to spend a day by the pool here. They offer pool pass and at the time we went they were $10 per person per day. The pool was super nice and clean, so are the restrooms. They offer towels here too, so you don't need to bring your own. Also around noon they start their poolside service if drinks and food. Very peaceful.

Wonderful place for a break from camping and enjoy some luxury in the desert.

Pool was very nice, only good thing to be said.

The Inn's prices are steep for a small room with very few amenities. While clean, the staff needs training as to proper house keeping requirements i.e. soap refills, hangers in the closet, door latch inoperative. The Inn's restaurant is likewise expensive, but understandable given its location. The menu offerings are limited and the portions are small. Having stayed at the ranch, there is much more value there. Their recent remodel took away much of the charm and added lots of expense.

A bit of unexpected beauty and history amidst the inhospitable expanse of Death Valley. The cave-like entrance is interesting. That it leads to such a polished and welcoming space is surprising and appreciated. Good drinks too!

We were married here. The customer service was wonderful the whole time. The bell hops, valet, receptionists, servers etc treated us, and our guests, wonderfully the whole time. The food and drinks are great and the location is beautiful and amazing. We truly felt pampered and cared for the entire time.

Perfect location in Death Valley.  The pool is wonderful. Overall atmosphere is exactly what I hoped it would be.  The food is very good but a little expensive.  We've stayed a few times here and hope to stay there again.

I love this place and try to come for dinner every year when I drive through DV.  The buildings and grounds are wonderful, especially at night, the staff is always really friendly and kind and the food never disappoints me.  It is like going back in time (in a good way) to visit here.  Have not stayed here--just eaten dinner 4 times.

Make sure you make dinner Reservations ahead of time. We couldn't have dinner until after 8pm even though we were guests of the hotel. There weren't many other options,  sit in the bar or starve. Hotel not worth the nearly $500.00 per night. Wifi terrible, we couldn't connect.
Had an amazing time at Furnace Creek with my family! Loved being there during the super bloom. The staff was incredible and so was the food to say nothing of the ambiance.

Very peaceful.
